tit.e: Oshioki Ruireishu (Judicial Precedents of Criminal Cases made by Edo bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun])

sen.j: 御仕置例類集（おしおきるいれいしゅう）とは、江戸幕府が作成した刑事事件に関する判例集。
sen.e: Oshiokiruireishu is a compilation of law reports dealing with criminal cases, which was created by the Edo shogunate.
Oshiokiruireishu is a compilation of law reports dealing with criminal cases, which was created by the Edo shogunate.
Oshioki Ruireishu was a compilation of law reports dealing with criminal cases, which was created by the Edo bakufu.

sen.j: 老中が各奉行から伺いが立てられた刑事事件に関する事案を評定所に諮問し、その答申である評議書を犯罪の事例、犯罪者の身分・年齢・性別などのよって分類・整理したもの。
sen.e: The roju (senior councillor of the Tokugawa shogunate) consulted Hyojosho about the criminal cases which each bugyo (magistrate) asked for the roju's judgement, and Oshiokiruireishu was created by classifying and sorting Hyogishos (reports from Hyojosho) by the type of crime, the status, the age, and the sexuality of each criminal.

The roju (senior councillor of the Tokugawa shogunate) consulted Hyojosho about the criminal cases which each bugyo (magistrate) had asked for the roju's judgement on, and Oshiokiruireishu was created by classifying and sorting Hyogishos (reports from Hyojosho) by the type of crime, status, age and gender of each criminal.
sen.cmt: The word "sexuality " is used to refer to someon's sexual preference i.e heteroseual, homosexual, bisexual etc.
sen.e: It was the documents by classifying and sorting Hyogisho, the reports of the criminal cases which each bugyo (magistrate) had asked the roju (senior councilor of the Tokugawa shogunate) to consult Hyojosho (conference chamber), by the case of crime, and the status, age, and gender of criminal, and so on.

sen.j: 複数回評議した記録や少数意見に関する記載についても載せられており、また公事方御定書の法解釈について触れていることから、御定書とともに極秘の扱いを受け、評定所・町奉行・勘定奉行・寺社奉行・京都所司代・大坂城代のみが保管を許されていた。
sen.e: Since it includes records of cases which were deliberated several times, minor opinions, and the legal interpretations of Kujigata-osadamegaki (the law of the Edo shogunate), it was treated as highly confidential information as well as Osadamegaki, and only organizations, which were machi bugyo (town magistrate), kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance), jisha bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines), Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy), Osaka jodai (the keeper of Osaka Castle), were allowed to store it.

It annotated records of cases which were deliberated several times and minority opinions, and since it touched on the legal interpretations of the law of the Edo shogunate ("Kujigata-osadamegaki"), it was treated, together with Osadamegaki, as highly confidential information, and only the town magistrate ("machi bugyo"), the commissioner of finance ("kanjo bugyo"), the magistrate of temples and shrines ("jisha bugyo"), the Kyoto deputy ("Kyoto shoshidai") or the keeper of Osaka Castle ("Osaka jodai") were allowed to store it.
